G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 212, §3, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of the Worcester District Court.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a73.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 212, §3, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of the Worcester District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a78.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court under G.L. c. 223, §8, as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Worcester County and the leased premises are located there.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord is prohibited from directly or indirectly interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of leased premises.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A.proposition: Plaintiff promptly reported these conditions to Defendant by direct communication and requested remedial measures consistent with the landlord’s obligations under G.L. c. 186, §14 and G.L. c. 239, §8A, as well as the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.550, which requires a landlord to maintain premises free from infestation.

105 CMR 410.550.proposition: Plaintiff’s loss of use and enjoyment is further supported by the requirement under the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.550, that “the owner shall maintain the dwelling free from rodents, insects, and other pests,” and failure to comply constitutes a breach of both statutory and common-law duties.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.proposition: The failure to maintain residential premises in a habitable condition, including the presence of rodents, constitutes a material interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address habitability or rodent infestation at all; it deals specifically with whether a statutory lead-paint violation, by itself, constitutes a violation of the Massachusetts quiet enjoyment statute. The court’s discussion of quiet enjoyment focuses on the need for at least negligent conduct and landlord notice, and cites other cases (including Dorgan) for failures to keep premises habitable, but Al‑Ziab itself does not establish that uninhabitable conditions such as rodents are a material interference with quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101\u201.proposition: The failure to maintain residential premises in a habitable condition, including the presence of rodents, constitutes a material interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly treats the repeated flooding and unsanitary conditions (water and sewage) as breaches of the warranty of habitability and interferences with quiet enjoyment, but it does not discuss rodents or other vermin as the basis for liability. The court even notes that although other problems such as rodents were mentioned, all three claims were submitted and decided on the theory that they arose from flooding. Thus, while the case supports the broader idea that unsanitary, uninhabitable conditions (like recurrent sewage flooding) materially interfere with quiet enjoyment, it does not itself establish that the presence of rodents constitutes such a material interference.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101\u201.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing. … These statutes are designed to facilitate enforcement of State housing regulations and to provide relief for tenants deprived of decent homes. … The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. … The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718.proposition: The failure to maintain residential premises in a habitable condition, including the presence of rodents, constitutes a material interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718.support_reasoning: The case concerns constructive eviction and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment due to excessive noise from a bar the landlord permitted and could control. It does not involve failure to maintain habitability in general or conditions such as rodents, nor does it discuss habitability standards or pests. While the court does link the noise to premises being “not reasonably habitable,” it does so only in the specific context of noise, not broader conditions like rodent infestation; thus it does not directly support the proposition about rodents and general habitability.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871 (.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that a landlord’s failure to correct unsanitary or unsafe conditions—including infestations—violates both the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871 (.support_reasoning: The opinion describes numerous serious defects in the apartment, including an infestation of cockroaches and rodents, and affirms liability for breach of the implied warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment, but it does not explicitly analyze or hold that unsanitary or unsafe conditions such as infestations, in and of themselves, constitute violations of those doctrines. The case focuses instead on emotional distress and Chapter 93A damages and on the measure of warranty damages; it does not articulate the specific legal principle stated in the proposition, nor does it present a line of cases "repeatedly" so holding. Thus it is not strong authority for that precise proposition, even though its facts are broadly consistent with it.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871 (.relevant_excerpt: “After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: … (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents…. Based on the findings, as summarized above, the judge found in favor of Gonzalez on each of her counterclaims…. On the G.L.c. 93A counterclaim, the judge found that Gonzalez had suffered two discrete injuries as a consequence of Haddad's unfair and deceptive trade practices: emotional distress, and the diminution in value of the apartment due to Haddad's breach of the warranty of habitability.”

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 197–200 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that a landlord’s failure to correct unsanitary or unsafe conditions—including infestations—violates both the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting portion discusses implied warranty of habitability and landlord obligations in relation to statutory housing and sanitary codes, but it does not specifically address infestations or clearly link unsanitary/unsafe conditions to both implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The focus is on how code violations inform an implied obligation to meet minimum standards and how that affects rent liability, not on repeated holdings regarding infestations or quiet enjoyment. Thus, it does not support the broader, infestation-specific proposition as stated.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”}

Winchester v. J.W. R. Co., Inc., 371 Mas.raw_text: Winchester v. J.W. R. Co., Inc., 371 Mass. 641, 646 (1976)
Winchester v. J.W. R. Co., Inc., 371 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s actions and omissions, including his failure to provide adequate extermination and to maintain sanitary conditions, constitute a constructive interference with Plaintiff’s tenancy in violation of G.L. c. 186, §14.
Winchester v. J.W. R. Co., Inc., 371 Mas.case_name: Zussman v. Rent Control Board of Brookline
Winchester v. J.W. R. Co., Inc., 371 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion is a rent control / confiscatory rate case dealing with standards of judicial review of rent control board decisions and what constitutes a reasonable rate of return. It does not involve landlord–tenant habitability issues, constructive interference with tenancy, or G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it discuss failures to exterminate or maintain sanitary conditions. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the claimed proposition about constructive interference with a tenancy under c. 186, § 14.
Winchester v. J.W. R. Co., Inc., 371 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "It will be remembered that in Marshal House, Inc. v. Rent Control Bd. of Brookline, 358 Mass. 686, 702-703 (1971), we read the term 'fair net operating income,' as it appears in St. 1970, cc. 842 and 843, 'to require that rents be set so as to assure to landlords a reasonable return on their investment.' That remains the governing standard in this Commonwealth today."

Mescall v. Somerset Properties Co., 18 M.raw_text: Mescall v. Somerset Properties Co., 18 Mass. App. Ct. 101, 104 (1984)
Mescall v. Somerset Properties Co., 18 M.proposition: Defendant’s actions and omissions, including his failure to provide adequate extermination and to maintain sanitary conditions, constitute a constructive interference with Plaintiff’s tenancy in violation of G.L. c. 186, §14.
Mescall v. Somerset Properties Co., 18 M.case_name: Ogden Suffolk Downs, Inc. v. City of Boston
Mescall v. Somerset Properties Co., 18 M.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns tax abatement interest under G.L. c. 59, § 69 and the retroactive application of St. 1980, c. 406. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, constructive interference with tenancy, habitability, or G.L. c. 186, § 14. Accordingly, it cannot support the proposition that a landlord’s failure to exterminate or maintain sanitary conditions constitutes constructive interference under that statute.
Mescall v. Somerset Properties Co., 18 M.relevant_excerpt: “The racetrack brought this complaint against the city of Boston in the Superior Court to recover an additional two per*102cent of interest which it claims to be due to it by reason of St. 1980, c. 406. The city contends that the 1980 statute does not apply to this refund of taxes assessed as of January 1, 1978… Our duty is to give these somewhat ambiguous words, ‘abatement filed,’ in c. 406, § 3, a reasonable construction which will carry out what we perceive to be the legislative intention.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Plaintiff’s loss of use and enjoyment is further supported by the requirement under the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.550, that “the owner shall maintain the dwelling free from rodents, insects, and other pests,” and failure to comply constitutes a breach of both statutory and common-law duties.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the State Sanitary Code as the source of the landlord’s duty to maintain habitable premises and recognizes that those duties cannot be waived. However, this case is about loss of heat and hot water, not rodents or 105 CMR 410.550 specifically, and it does not state that violation of that particular regulation constitutes a breach of both statutory and common-law duties. The proposition over-reads the case by tying it to a specific pest-control requirement that Berman does not address.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “For example, the State Sanitary Code, adopted pursuant to authority granted in G. L. c. 111, § 5 (since amended, see G. L. c. 111, § 127A, for the current version), imposed on the landlord a duty to maintain an apartment in habitable condition, so the landlord could fairly expect and be expected to keep his rented premises habitable… The landlord can have no reasonable grounds to believe that noncompliance will be acceptable.”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 908 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Plaintiff’s loss of use and enjoyment is further supported by the requirement under the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.550, that “the owner shall maintain the dwelling free from rodents, insects, and other pests,” and failure to comply constitutes a breach of both statutory and common-law duties.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion notes that there were various State Sanitary Code violations in the apartment, including mice and ants, but it does not quote or analyze 105 CMR 410.550, does not state that the sanitary code requires the owner to maintain the dwelling free from rodents and other pests, and does not discuss that noncompliance constitutes a breach of statutory and common‑law duties. The case instead focuses on utilities, security deposits, rent control, habitability damages generally, and G.L. c. 93A, without using the pest‑control provision as a basis for its legal conclusions. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt:
"Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property.2 The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs."

"The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks."
